cards.title: Athletics / Sally Pearson feared amputation of her lower arm after hurdles fall in Rome
cards.rawTitle: Sally Pearson feared amputation of her lower arm after hurdles fall in Rome

item.title: Sally Pearson feared amputation of her lower arm after hurdles fall in Rome
item.trailText: The Olympic 100 metres hurdles champion Sally Pearson has been ruled out of the world championships after she broke her left arm
item.standFirst:
• Australian suffered ‘bone explosion’ in her wrist
• Olympic champion to miss world championships
item.body:
The Olympic 100 metres hurdles champion Sally Pearson feared she might have to have her lower arm amputated after she broke it in a “traumatic” fall at the Rome Diamond League meeting earlier this month.

Pearson has been ruled out of this year’s world championships after she sustained the injury, which doctors described as a “bone explosion” in her wrist.

“I was terrified seeing my hand going in a different direction,” she said. “I thought they would have to amputate.

Related: Usain Bolt wins 200m in New York but sluggish display 'looks like trouble'

“I’ve never broken a bone, I’ve never had stitches or surgery before,” Pearson said. “Doing all of that in one, in a different country, was very traumatic for me.

“But I do put things into perspective and think I am very lucky with what happened. If it had been the ankle, it would be a completely different story right now and I’d be telling you something different.”

The 28-year-old Australian, who won the sprint hurdle world title in 2011 and finished second behind the American Brianna Rollins in Moscow two years later, had surgery on the injury in Italy but will require another operation on Tuesday.

She said she was disappointed to miss out on the August world championships in Beijing, where she won silver at the 2008 Olympics, but thought the enforced rest might help her bid to retain her 2012 Olympic title in Rio de Janeiro.

“I guess I haven’t had a break since 2003, my first Australian team,” she added. “I think this will be a very good mental and physical break for me leading into the Olympics next year.”

Australia’s head coach Craig Hilliard said it was a major blow to lose the country’s most successful current track and field athlete from the team.

“Sally’s our team captain and she gives great leadership and gets on really well with all the athletes,” he said. “It will be a big loss but the critical thing is that she needs time mentally and physically to get over this.”

displayImages.caption: Sally Pearson shouts in pain after falling during the women's 100 hurdles at the Diamond League meeting in Rome. Photograph: Alessandro Di Meo/AP
displayImages.credit: Alessandro Di Meo/AP
displayImages.altText: sally pearson
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sally Pearson shouts in pain after falling during the women's 100 hurdles at the Diamond League meeting in Rome. Photograph: Alessandro Di Meo/AP

cards.title: Rugby league / NRL: Parramatta Eels' season worsens as CEO steps down
cards.rawTitle: NRL: Parramatta Eels' season worsens as CEO steps down

item.title: NRL: Parramatta Eels' season worsens as CEO steps down
item.trailText: Parramatta CEO Scott Seward has stepped down from the embattled club in the wake of the club’s poor start to the season and salary cap dramas
item.standFirst: • CEO Scott Seward steps down amid salary caps infringements and poor form
item.body:
Parramatta CEO Scott Seward has stepped down from the embattled club in the wake of the club’s poor start to the season and salary cap dramas.

Seward on Sunday informed club chairman Steve Sharp that he would leave the Eels immediately citing personal reasons.

He had been under pressure after the team slumped to second last on the NRL ladder and was fined $525,000 for salary cap overspending.

The club’s chief operating officer John Boulous has been appointed acting CEO while head of football operations Daniel Anderson will handle football administrative responsibilities previously handled by the CEO.

The Eels were handed a breach notice for overspending in four of the NRL’s salary cap categories last year.

The NRL also threatened to deduct four competition points next year unless an independent review of the club is undertaken.

The club has challenged some of the rulings.

The Eels are under pressure placed second last on the ladder with just four wins from 13 games this season.

displayImages.credit: Paul Miller/AAP
displayImages.altText: Parramatta Eels

headerImage.caption: Anthony Watmough of Parramatta leaves the field following their loss to the Cowboys during the round 13 NRL match between the Parramatta Eels and the North Queensland Cowboys. Photograph: Paul Miller/AAP
headerImage.cleanCaption: Anthony Watmough of Parramatta leaves the field following their loss to the Cowboys during the round 13 NRL match between the Parramatta Eels and the North Queensland Cowboys.

snap.title: NRL: Parramatta Eels' season worsens as CEO steps down

image.credit: Paul Miller/AAP
image.altText: Parramatta Eels

cards.title: Snooker / Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
cards.rawTitle: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion

item.title: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
item.trailText: Tug of war and baseball are also among a list of 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Games, before a shortlist is announced on 26 June
item.standFirst:
• Tug of war and baseball also among 26 sports to have applied for Tokyo Games
• Shortlist will be announced on 26 June before final decision next August
item.body:
Snooker, chess, bridge and tug of war are among the 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.

Baseball and softball have also applied, as has squash, after they were the sports to miss out when wrestling was reinstated by the International Olympic Committee in 2013 having initially been dropped for 2020.

Squash will be hoping to be included for the first time after missing out to golf and rugby sevens for the 2016 Games while baseball and softball, popular in Japan, is bidding to return having been dropped following Beijing 2008.

The Tokyo 2020 additional event programme panel will now narrow the 26 applicants down to a shortlist to be announced on 22 June, with a final decision due to be made by the IOC in August next year.

The decision will be made based on whether the applicant can “serve as a driving force to promote the Olympic movement and its values, with a focus on youth appeal” and “add value to the Games by engaging the Japanese population and new audiences worldwide, reflecting the Tokyo 2020 Games vision”.

The traditional Japanese sport of sumo has also lodged an application as have karate, American football, tenpin bowling, polo and orienteering.

Full list of federations to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games

World Air Sports Federation (FAI), International Federation of American Football (IFAF), World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC), World Confederation of Billiards Sports (WCBS), Bowls Sports World Confederation (CMSB), World Bowling (WB), World Bridge Federation (WBF), World Chess Federation (FIDE), World DanceSport Federation (WDSF), International Floorball Federation (IFF), World Flying Disc Federation (WFDF), World Karate Federation (WKF), International Korfball Federation (IKF), International Netball Federation (INF), International Orienteering Federation (IOF), Federation of International Polo (FIP), International Racquetball Federation (IRF), International Federation of Roller Sports (FIRS), International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC), World Squash Federation (WSF), International Sumo Federation (IFS), International Surfing Association (ISA), Tug of War International Federation (TWIF), World Underwater Federation (CMAS), International Waterski & Wakeboard Federation (IWWF), International Wushu Federation (IWUF).

item.title: Steph Curry: Golden State Warriors confident of sealing NBA glory
item.trailText: Steph Curry, the Golden State Warriors' guard, comments on his team's progress in the NBA Finals, following the Warriors' 104-91 victory against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Sunday night
item.standFirst: Steph Curry, the Golden State Warriors' guard, comments on his team's progress in the NBA Finals, following the Warriors' 104-91 victory against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Sunday night. This latest win brings the series score to 3-2 in favour of the Warriors, before the next match against the Cavaliers in Cleveland on Wednesday

cards.title: Sailing / Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight
item.trailText: The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France.
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and will visit 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months.
• More of the best images from the Volvo Ocean Race so far

item.title: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
item.trailText: Tug of war and baseball are also among a list of 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Games, before a shortlist is announced on 26 June
item.standFirst:
• Tug of war and baseball also among 26 sports to have applied for Tokyo Games
• Shortlist will be announced on 26 June before final decision next August
item.body:
Snooker, chess, bridge and tug of war are among the 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.

Baseball and softball have also applied, as has squash, after they were the sports to miss out when wrestling was reinstated by the International Olympic Committee in 2013 having initially been dropped for 2020.

Squash will be hoping to be included for the first time after missing out to golf and rugby sevens for the 2016 Games while baseball and softball, popular in Japan, is bidding to return having been dropped following Beijing 2008.

The Tokyo 2020 additional event programme panel will now narrow the 26 applicants down to a shortlist to be announced on 22 June, with a final decision due to be made by the IOC in August next year.

The decision will be made based on whether the applicant can “serve as a driving force to promote the Olympic movement and its values, with a focus on youth appeal” and “add value to the Games by engaging the Japanese population and new audiences worldwide, reflecting the Tokyo 2020 Games vision”.

The traditional Japanese sport of sumo has also lodged an application as have karate, American football, tenpin bowling, polo and orienteering.

Full list of federations to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games

World Air Sports Federation (FAI), International Federation of American Football (IFAF), World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC), World Confederation of Billiards Sports (WCBS), Bowls Sports World Confederation (CMSB), World Bowling (WB), World Bridge Federation (WBF), World Chess Federation (FIDE), World DanceSport Federation (WDSF), International Floorball Federation (IFF), World Flying Disc Federation (WFDF), World Karate Federation (WKF), International Korfball Federation (IKF), International Netball Federation (INF), International Orienteering Federation (IOF), Federation of International Polo (FIP), International Racquetball Federation (IRF), International Federation of Roller Sports (FIRS), International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC), World Squash Federation (WSF), International Sumo Federation (IFS), International Surfing Association (ISA), Tug of War International Federation (TWIF), World Underwater Federation (CMAS), International Waterski & Wakeboard Federation (IWWF), International Wushu Federation (IWUF).
